Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2013 05:03PM ReneeinOH wrote: What he described about how long it takes to get the report, follow up meeting is typical.  When they remove, they want to make sure they have "clear margins," which is why he is looking at the surrounding tissue.  You certainly could go for a second opinion, and should if you are not comfortable with your dr.'s approach, or not clear what is going on with you.  I don't know if an MRI is warranted in your case.  MRIs can also have a lot of false-positives.  I had an MRI  done on both breasts, but that came after my biopsy came back positive for cancer. Hoping they find your lump benign.
Posts.Title: Surgeon wants to remove it... Freaking Out- Have Questions nlmlillysmom chef127

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 05:13AM ReneeinOH wrote: Sorry you are going through this MoominMama.  Waiting for answers is excruciating.  Please don't go there and think the worst (easier said than done, I know).  The best thing to do is distract yourself, be good to yourself to make the time pass.  The worst thing you can do is check out Dr. Google.  You won't be able to diagnose yourself, but will succeed in scaring yourself.
Posts.Title: So scared. MoominMama Gingerbrew

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2013 04:57PM ReneeinOH wrote: So sorry that you've joined this club that no one wants to be part of.  Peggy gives great guidance.  Depending how public you want to be, you can also ask around.  I PMed all my women friends on Facebook that live in my area.  It's kind of shocking how many had a relative or friend who had a dr. to recommend, and in a couple of cases, people connected in the breast cancer services community.  There is a lot to be said about going to a breast cancer center, where the doctors can work as a team, but not everyone has that option and needs to pull their team together.  If you haven't found this, you might want to read through this section of the website (since you're picking up your pathology report): http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/getting_path_report Keep asking for feedback here, if you need it.  You don't have to go through this alone.

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2013 06:29AM ReneeinOH wrote: Bevin has suggested some great ideas for getting support, and I hope you reach out.  Since you posted in the not diagnosed but worried section, I am assuming you haven't been told you have cancer.  The statistics are on your side.  If remembering correctly, 80% of biopsies come back benign.  I know I can't offer words that will comfort you or make you feel better about the trials your life has been through.  Just know there are other people here who can relate, and are a great source of support and information.  ((((hugs to you)))))
Posts.Title: flat hard lump, size of quarter, ujst under the skin Razin3rats LaurenN

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 04:22PM ReneeinOH wrote: Maybe your mom's dr. is taking her age and overall health into consideration (?).  Recovering from a double mastectomy is usually harder than a single mastectomy. As been said before, it is a personal choice.  I initially wanted a double, but after my breast surgeon said it was more likely that cancer would show up elsewhere in my body than the healthy breast, I changed my mind.  I also came to acceptance of the tests, monitoring I'll have to be dealing with from this point on. Initially I bristled at the scans, etc. that I face, but learned I'm going to be a breast cancer patient one way or another, and feel confident in my dr.'s plan to monitor.  And, I take comfort in having my native breast.  In the beginning of this, for me, I viewed my breasts as ticking time bombs, but that feeling dissipated.  It's a big decision.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 09:00PM ReneeinOH wrote: Thanks Debbie!  I came up BRCA 1&2-.  Dr. is treating it as if there is no gene link, but I have to wonder for me, that genetics is factoring into this.  I'm 45.  My mom was dx w/BC when she was in her early 70s. Sister w/DCIS when she was 47.  My mom had no other (female siblings).  My grandfather died of colon cancer.  And my dad's side is a freaking disaster.  He had esophogeal cancer.  Five out of his six sisters (my aunts) had cancer of some sort--three of them breast, and one of those three got it in her 40s and died.  The sister who didn't have cancer had a daughter (my cousin) w/ovarian cancer and she died in her 40s. I had been prepared to have a BMX if my gene. test came back positive.  But, now I'm set for a MX, following dr.'s advice.

Posts.Title: mamm & ultrasound confirmed lump.dr skipped tests? kimi11 ReneeinOH

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2015 12:56AM ReneeinOH wrote: Welcome to the club that no one wants to be a part of. We all have been where you are at, feeling what you feel. It is normal to want to understand exactly what you are dealing with, and what you need to do to get rid of whatever you are facing. Cut it out, cut off my breasts, so long as I can beat this and never deal with this again. So this is why people will say this is the worst part--the not knowing. And, it takes some time to figure out what is going on, which is needed to understand what treatments are needed. The best things you can do at this point is to educate yourself--not on Dr. Google; the articles on bco are fantastic and will teach you about breast cancer, how diagnosis works, what to expect with surgery, treatment, and so on. That way, as your dr. talks to you, you will be familiar with terms, etc. It is a lot to absorb, but you will get there. And you are not alone--there is a lot of support here. It doesn't feel it right now, but trust me when I say you will not feel as scared or devastated. It sucks to have to deal with, but you can do this.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2013 11:19PM ReneeinOH wrote: So sorry that you are joining us, but know we are here for you lstewart51.  It's a lot to take in, and over time, you will better understand all of this, as well as feel less anxious once a treatment plan is IDed and underway.  There are so many resources here.  If you haven't read the explanations on BCO, I highly recommend you do so.  This may be a good place to start: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms  The discussion boards are full of helpful threads, including getting ready for chemo: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/706846?page=39#post_3537445 You're welcome to join other sisters with IDC in this group: http://community.breastcancer.org/topic_post?forum_id=96&id=798679&page=28  Another sister, Laura, recently joined us who is at stage 3 and her starting treatment is chemo.  It helps to have a partner to go through this together, and that's what we do here.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2013 10:51AM ReneeinOH wrote: Hi ladies, Just to share my experience: I ended up with an oncotype score of 11, and as my stats show, no nodes involved, grade 2 tumor. I met w/my MO, who recommended no chemo.  As Annice (and others? have shared), she said chemo would only reduce recurrence chance 2-3%, and risks outweigh any benefit.  She said one of the benefits that chemo would have on me (pre-menopausal) is chemopause--stopping my periods, so instead she started me on Zoladex (monthly shot in my belly), which will shut down my ovaries (=stop producing estrogen).  In addition, I will start Tamoxifen next month--be on that for 5 years, and then on an AI 5 years after that.  She also will put me on Zometa (every three months), which helps with bone density, and studies are showing that there's additional benefit to reducing recurrence. When I asked my MO about longer term, where will I be with all of this, she was optimistic.  On top of me being statistically in good shape, she said I'd be on these estrogen suppressing treatments for the next 10 years (starving any cancer trying to get a foothold) and 10 years from now we'll have that much more information about BC treatments.
Posts.Title: In your 40's with low Oncotype score, what was your decision? gracebead p22nut5

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 07:21AM ReneeinOH wrote: I am new to this journey too shadytrake.  What everyone has said is spot on.  All I can add is the shock will wear off and you will step up.  I don't have the challenge of menopause, and can only imagine how much harder this makes things for you. My brother is a chiropractor, and while he wants me to do complementary approaches (which I can see a lot of value in), he has said my body is in crisis and to go full force medically.  So it doesn't have to be an eiher-or.  Ultimately you get to choose.  You get to put yourself first.  If your friend continues to make things more difficult for you, you tell her you love her, but she has to back off and leave you alone.  Completely stop.  I think we all deal with unhelpful suggestions and opinions (hardest though when it comes from people closest to us), but we can make our own decisions and not feel obligated to heed any suggestions that doesn't sit well with us (coming from professionals or friends and family).
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed shadytrake beacon800

Posts.Content: May 26, 2013 03:19PM ReneeinOH wrote: dim, there are explanations of all of this on the BCO site: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis  Take some time to to get your head around your diagnosis, and treatment protocol (here's chemo: http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/chemotherapy)  There are a lot of threads on the discussion board that can be a source for information and to have specific questions answered.  For instance, here's a thread about getting ready for chemo: community.breastcancer.org/for...  While it cannot completely eliminate the fear, understanding what you are facing will reduce the anxiety.  I also hope that knowing others have walked similiar paths as you, and gotten through this, is of some comfort. We are here on the discussion boards to support each other, as well as ourselves. Grade one is a slow growing tumor--that is a very good thing, btw.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2013 10:11PM ReneeinOH wrote: My surgeon suggested taking Melatonin to see how that works before moving into a prescription drug.  I found it does relax me.  It doesn't knock me out, so I do find I wake sometimes during the night, but I find it easy to get back to sleep (unlike using nothing).  Actually smaller doses work better; my understanding is larger doses can end up having less effect.  I also stopped drinking alcohol (i've been a one glass of red wine a night kind of gal); I think that is helping.  Sleep deprivation makes all of this a million times harder, so do what you can to get some better sleep.
